text: hiya everyone Anthony Fantana here
internets busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new la dispute
record the rooms of the house these guys
are a Michigan band
ten years going strong this is their
third full-length LP and over the years
they have evolved to become one of the
most idiosyncratic bands an emo and post
hardcore pairing the punk spirit and a
lot of guitars of these genres with some
incredibly vivid and wordy storytelling
and this storytelling really reached a
peak in the band's career on their last
full-length LP wild life dropped in 2011
and is still remains one of my favorite
albums of that year grows on me with
every listen oh God
such a good record if you haven't heard
this record please freaking listen to
this record really powerful tales all
over this album backed with some great
rock instrumentation there's a track on
here the kind of details the decline and
hopeful restoration of a church losing a
child to cancer the destruction of some
teenage kids life by anti-depression
medication a deadly shooting and then
subsequent arrests frontman jordan
Dreyer's lyrics and singing are winding
they're powerful they're loaded with
just rollercoaster emotions climaxes
plot twists and the instrumentation the
band conjured to go behind these lyrics
felt like they complemented the
storyline of these tracks at every shift
in gear that was made it's not like
listening to a rock band cycle through a
simple series of verses and choruses and
even though all the tales laden into
these songs are different it is the
themes of emotional exorcism and
catharsis and metaphorically getting
things off of the chest that brings a
lot of these tracks together and leaves
this album feeling kind of like a
concept or very thematic now widest pews
back with the new full-length record
rooms of the house and on this LP it
seems that the band continues to take
underground rock music and apply very
true
maduk wordy thought-provoking lyrics
stories poems to it but there are some
somewhat obvious changes that La Dispute
presents for example this is the band
shortest full-length LP so far and is a
little more concise than the records
they have put out in the past there's
not a single song on here that
approaches the five-minute mark and
there are a few tracks on this LP as
well that have faintly catchy and very
straightforward guitar riffs or chords
on a lot of songs here instrumentally
anyway la dispute is no longer indulging
in these winding evolving pieces of rock
music in fact there are a handful of
songs on this LP that instrumentally are
kind of subdued which in one breath is
kind of disappointing but in another I
do think that has led to rooms of the
house being the most varied lot of speed
record today take the kind of subdued
hypnotic drumbeat hanging in the
background on the track woman in mirror
these strung out guitars and the sort of
lacks spoken word vocals seem faintly
Slynt esque on this song and then
there's the song extraordinary dinner
party which opens up with this winning
set of melodic chords that if it wasn't
in this track I think could have played
well into a an old-school dinosaur
junior song production-wise la dispute
sounds roughly roughly the same there
are quite a few tracks on here where the
guitars are noticeably legally louder
than they have been on previous LPS and
I would say with any other band that
could have been a great thing but in
this particular instance it makes at
least on some songs to me especially the
second track here
it makes the lyrics it makes the vocals
so much more difficult to read to make
out there are moments where I really
think it makes them kind of
unintelligible and again for any other
band that might not necessarily be a
horrible thing but for La Dispute the
lyrics just carry the songs so much it
seems like the spotlight on this record
even more than usual is being shifted
away from Jeremy and to the characters
that he's singing about it's again a
very slight change not big enough to
signify a huge
in the band sound which could be a good
or a bad thing with rooms of the house
because for some coming into this record
it may seem like La Dispute is just kind
of putting together a by-the-numbers
sort of LP which I understand could be
kind of a hard feeling to avoid
considering how unique and specific La
Dispute sound is and on top of that any
changes they make to their usual sound
could seem really great sort of like the
downstroke slow and kind of punky guitar
chords on the track the mayor and
splitsville outside of the context of
this record when I was first exposed to
this song and many other people too it
seemed like this track could have been a
grab for a poppier sound or even an
attempt at just a stronger element of
accessibility but in the context of the
record I do like the song a lot more and
I do kind of see these guitar courts
kicking off the first verse of the album
as sort of reclaiming a rock lovesong
cliche because as the song progresses it
does reveal some really great chord
progressions and pretty explosive
moments too now like la disputes last
album this LP too seems to just kind of
be a mixed bag of different tales
however these don't feel strung together
by the same themes of incredible
emotional and sometimes physical trauma
still it does not make this LP any less
powerful as it kicks off with the track
Hudsonville michigan 1956 a song that
sets a scene with a woman who's in
indiana her husband is over in michigan
there's a tornado there's a storm
she's shuffling the kids downstairs for
shelter there's a bulletin over the
radio the song gets really intense as
does the track 35 a song that I believe
is actually referenced on this opening
track here and on this track Jeremy
gives us a view of this incredible car
accident involving many vehicles and
people falling to their demise on a
bridge that seems to give way it seems
that this incredibly horrific event is
actually a bit of a centerpiece on this
record I actually think this records
king Park if you will and it is
referenced on these
stay happy there as well as the narrator
of this track is sort of contemplating
this relationship he's seeing demise in
front of him thinking about everything
that could have been in the future
whether or not that everything occurred
in the past throughout this relationship
was sort of a waste of time however
there are some tails on this record that
do not feel quite as grand in topic but
it doesn't seem like the band puts any
less effort into the storytelling or
doesn't try to put any less urgency into
the instrumentation for example scenes
from highways from 1981 to 2009 which
seems to contain a lot of intimate
reflections on the past with this
particular character that we're
following on this record and while this
track and no other track on here as well
don't feel like a huge disappointment to
me it's very clear that this record
overall is not quite as elaborate or as
extravagant as a lot of spews pass to
falling kelpies the gap here isn't huge
but it's noticeable and I think it's due
to the Bands more concise approach on
this record I feel like they are trying
to make their instrumentation a little
more straightforward on these tracks and
a little louder a little brighter a
little punchier and yet they don't try
to alter their lyrical approach
significantly and I think what they've
ended up is just trying to put ten
pounds of magic inside of a five pound
bag to me this kind of lyricism in this
kind of instrumentation needs more space
needs more time it does not need a
really hooky looped drumbeat
it does not need a really obvious
attempt to try to pull everything
together on the closing track which
while conceptually interesting is kind
of an anti climactic finish and it
doesn't necessarily need slightly louder
guitars either overall I do think that
this is a very good record from La
Dispute but I didn't come out of this
thing as infatuated with it as I have
been with their two previous records
still there are plenty of clever
metaphors on this LP and allegory
involving rooms houses
furniture material things a dying
relationship and of course there are a
few detours as well into personal and
widespread disaster I'm feeling a decent
of strong seven on this thing transition
